(Freshmen Seminar - Limited to First-Year Students Only)
For my PHIL 190: Thoreau's Walden
Course Description: Thoreau's Walden tries to reimagine what life could be like under conditions of increasing industrialization and commercialization. Convinced that his peers lead lives of "quiet desperation," living only to work to pay bills, he experiments with a simplified economy that leaves room for the pursuit of an ecologically oriented cosmopolitanism. We will read the whole of Walden, focusing on the various positions it develops, and how, as a rhetorical whole, it pursues moral reform. 
Required Texts: There is one book for the course, the third edition of the Norton Critical Edition of Walden. Students must use this edition. 
Henry David Thoreau. Walden, Civil Disobedience, and Other Writings. 3rd Edition. Ed. William Rossi. W.W. Norton & Company. ISB# 9780393930900.
Grading Details: Students will: (a) write short, one-page, weekly papers, graded P/NP; (b) an expository paper, 4-5 pages graded A, B, etc.; (c) a 6-8 page term paper exploring a chapter of your choice, which will be written in stages, including a full draft and ensuing revision; and (d) participate in a group presentation to be delivered during the second part of the semester. Finally, attendance is required.
